These are good bagels, and early enough on a Saturday morning, easy to drive to/not be in 16th crowds, and WAY better than any other place around (save for House of Bagels, which are the BEST in SF, but on the other side of town).

Loved my experience popping in for a dozen to bring to a friend's brunch.  The cream cheeses are great (the honey-some/nut) which does make it more desirable to House of Bagels and its reasonably priced.  

At 11am they were out of Everythings, which I think is fairly atrocious since that's the only way I can truely judge a bagel against its siblings.

My only saddness: why did I live in the mission 10 blocks away for so long without making this place a stop for a weekly supply every now and again.  What a(n east-coast) treat!
author: Sarah X.

description:
Katz Bagels are excellent. Jalepeno bagels = hot stuff. 
Slices of lox +  capers + cream cheese = utmost awesomeness.
author: Dan S.

description:
i should've known that katz wasn't going to deliver on pizza awesomeness when i saw that no one was inside ordering, eating, or milling about.  still, i thought i'd give it a shot.  

one pesto slice to go, please.  

...  

i couldn't even finish my slice, which says a lot, given my affinity to junk food.  ...it was loaded w/butter.  BUTTER!  LOTS OF IT!  WHY?  (in case you didn't catch it, gratuitous caps lock = outright disbelief.)  there could've easily been a half of a stick in the slice that i was trying to finish.  my dining companions didn't enjoy their pizza either.

so much for decent nourishment to play some proper pool.  instead, i almost got into it w/a dbag at kilowatt.  grrrrr.  tainted butter?  make ting turn into incredible hulk.  ...err, incredibly tiny hulk, anyway.
author: Ting A.

description: I grew up in upstate NY, and have always felt one of the few food areas SF really couldn't do was east coast style pizza. To give some perspective, I think Arinell's and Lanesplitter do a pretty good job. Just stopped into Katz for some late night (but not drunk- important distinction) pizza, and I have say, I was very impressed. Thin crust but not too crispy, good mix of toppings (ham, sausage, bacon, bell peppers, jalapeños). Glad I gave this a shot instead of falling back on Arinell's.
author: Katherine M.

description: The staff here are really nice and friendly.  I only ordered a hot beverage but it stayed warm for a really long time.  Longer than most places if I recall correctly.  I saw a bunch of people buying pizzas that looked mighty tasty.  I'll have to go back and try them sometime.  I have nothing but love for you guys and gals here.
author: Amy J.

description:
Review for KATZ BAGELS' PIZZA:  Unfortunately, NOT pizza with a bagel crust which I've encountered in Venice Beach of all places (late night pizza goodness), and if you're familiar with Katz' pizza bagels sold at Rainbow Grocery, then you can understand when I heard that Katz on 16th had pizza I HAD to find out whether it was a bagel crust.  

Unfortunately (again), they are touting themselves as thin crust, and it just doesn't cut it.  Tonight was my first foray into their 'Mission' pizza:  pepperoni, sausage, white onion, black olives with mozz and red sauce.  Well, the sauce was yum if not a little salty but that may have been the black olives which are super salty (at least proves they're fresh).  And, the crust while thin is NOT crispy which where I've been (New York, Chicago) thin crust means crispy, or at least, not soggy which is when the pizza is wet (from the toppings and sauce leaching liquid) and easily folds down with cheese and toppings sliding off onto your lap if you're not lucky.  I'm not wearing their toppings, but the crust was definitely soggy.  There wasn't even char on the bottom (sign of a good, strong pizza oven)!

My friend said, "I don't like pizza that falls apart like this."  This is not to say that the pizza was not good although he did say something about not liking the sausage which is probably because it's slices of sausage rather than crumbled sausage which some people prefer (I prefer SHAVED sausage).  Again, good flavour-- sauce, toppings taste fresh (and LOOK fresh on the mise en place line which replaces the bagel smears and toppings from the breakfast shift)-- and you can't beat 16th street for atmosphere.  

The crust  still needs work-- it's very non-descript, if not overly chewy from overworked dough.  This is not how their bagels taste-- they're perfectly chewy with that extra West Coast fluffliness (remember, it's the water here not the technique)-- so that would have been clever to taste in a pizza crust (would it have tasted like a hotpocket?), at least the tangy flavour of boiled dough would have been more interesting than what they've got going now.

The pizza at katz is relatively new, so I'll wait for them to work out the kinks.  The other pizza designs look promising-- the Kat's pizza:  arugula, chokes, prosciutto, parmesan (viva los foodies!)-- so I'll check them in a few months.  They better hook it up real fast though, as Little Star appears to be opening a satellite on 14th and Mish.
author: E L.

description: Pretty damn good slice of reheated pizza! I think I actually preferred it this way as oppose to it being made fresh, the crust was nice & crispy!!
author: Elfego F.

description: Okay coffee, okay bagel, waited in longish line for no apparent reason. Meh.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Katz. Oh Katz.  I used to live in literally a stones throw away from Katz (i tried hitting the bagel saucer once from my roof...ok so i didn't but if I had wanted to I could have!) Needless to say they were responsible for about 4 out of 5 breakfasts I had on the way to work. 

I love the bagels, just like my jewish grandma made (if she were a bagel maker which she is not...but she is jewish...). The spreads are amazing (try my fav. dill cucumber). And even after not living there for 2 years the staff still remembers my name. I feel like i'm on cheers.
author: Molly W.

description: I need a bagel fix sometimes. They deliver the goods year in and year out. the real boiled goods and I think you know what I'm talkin' about.
author: ari s.

description:
Nice little bagel place in a spot that aspired to be upscalish-Mexican... they do their lox bagels really well -- with delicate smoked salmon (not too salty or fishy), expertly-thin-sliced onion and tomato, caper dots and generous schmears of cream cheese...

Cash only, and I've often run across several patrons making a mad dash back out to the ATM....
author: Claudine C.

description: It's a bagel shop that is fast, efficient, tasty, and super cheap. (my large coffee and bagel w/cream cheese, cucumbers and tomatoe = $5)!  As an added bonus, they make your coffee fresh, one cup at a time...delicious!  To nay sayers, or peeps that give it anything lower than four stars I say...it's a bagel shop, if you want something fancy go have yourself a sit down breakfast because you are not in the mood for a bagel!
author: ada l.

description: This place is definitely not the same as it used to be. Seems that they are now making pizza. I have yet to experience that, but a few years back, I would have gone there just for the bagels and I live clear across town. I ended up there the other day trying to relive culinary bliss and was disappointed. Seems from posts here that there is new ownership. It is a shame... bring back the old Katz! I go now because it is there and I am close by, but I truly miss the old Katz. Might as well go to cafetazo and get a bagel there.
author: Amelia M.

description:
I ordered the Mission slice, with extra Tapatio sauce for added kick. My oh my, is it tasty. Not only that, but the guy who was taking the ordered treated my like I was his best, most honored homie from when we used to spark J's in Mexico City in '77.

I read the SF Chronicle, ate that slice, shook the man's hand, and felt like a champion. Feeling like a champion deserves 5 stars.
author: Haz O.

description:
Quite simply a bagel is dough. In order to be delicious, in my estimation, you need something more...perhaps in this case the Katz bagel people understood, you need much less. 

Have you ever eaten a bagel from Noah's Bagels and wonder how you managed to stuff down that whole loaf of fluffy bread? This is Katz' strong point. The bagels aren't jumbo the dough is the right consistency and the taste can't be beat.
author: Jessica D.

description:
Katz's is a bagel place so could it possibly have good pizza as well?  I haven't ever seen a place that can make good bagels and pizza.

The pizza at Katz's was good and a solid three rating.  The slice is fresh as it is made from scratch after you order the slice.  There is really nothing amazing about the slice but it is fundamentally sound as a NY thin crust slice.
author: Josh K.

description:
Hmm. Not sure what happened at the 16th st. store. Seems like bagels are low priority these days. I used to wake up on the weekend excited to spend my money here. No longer. 
Twice now (since they have started their renovations) they did not have everything bagels nor their chive Toffuti cream cheese. I was informed they no longer make the chive version.
I got the regular Toffuti: they were sparse with the spread, seriously sparse. And then to top it off the tomatoes were gritty and slimy.... at 11:00am...
Won't see me sitting there anymore.
author: Maria L.

description: Friendly staff, great prices and service, lots of options, delicious coffee... I have no complaints. This is a great place to stop for a quick breakfast before work.
author: Barron K.

description:
It's hard to miss this place with the big ol bagel hanging outside of the store front. If you are searching for a really good, reasonably priced bagel in the Mission, this is your place.

It's cash only but there are ATMs nearby.

Also, next time I come in, I am going to check out the photography book they have on sale. Looks like its the work of a local photographer who took photos around San Francisco. Thumbs up to any business who supports local artists.

Did I mention their bagels are super good? They are. Way better than Noahs by a long shot!
author: Kathleen N.

description: A shockingly good slice of cheese pizza.  I'm coming back.
author: Dan S.

description:
Being the creature of habit that I am, I get the same thing every time I go there - dill cheddar bagel with the pesto garlic spread and a large coffee - and I have never been disappointed. Plus they are always friendly. Plus it's less than a block from my home. 

My husband can't stand their bagels. Apparently, they don't do a proper breakfast bagel. I'm not a big fan of breakfast bagels, so I wouldn't know anything about their inadequacy in that department, but his complaint seems to be related to their treatment of the egg component. In honor and respect of my hubby, I gotta knock off a star.

But like I said, I always leave satisfied.
author: Amy K.

description: My ex-roommate used to work here and hated it. But I think they're brilliant. Great food, quick service, and decent coffee on the fly. Lots of locals frequent this location and once you go, it's easy to see why. I dinged them a star for not having any reasonable parking.
author: Sam A.

description: Katz is not so much a bagel shop as it is a generic coffee and sandwich place that happens to serve things on bagels.  What stands out about them?  Not bagel selection (there's like what, 8 kinds?).  Not unique and tasty sandwiches (I've had better bacon egg and cheese bagels at many a non-bagel eatery).  They don't even have that giant bagel-shaped marquee anymore.  What's up with that?  Stick with House of Bagels or the Bagel Bakery.
author: Wes M.

description:
OK, their bagels are more like 3.5 - 4 stars, probably the best in the Bay. Most bagels here are just bread with a hole in it - these are at least really bagels. And i'm soooper thankful for that! So we'll start with 4 stars.

Subtract 1 star for microwaving their eggs, bacon, etc. What is this, the airport?

Subtract 1 star for closing hella early. I know, everyone else does it here, but that doesn't make it OK. And WTF is up with closing even earlier on Sunday? Say it with me: Katz. Bagels. Does that not sound Jewish to you? Does your Rabbi know you're staying open on Shabbos and closing early on the Sabbath?

Meh.

PS, three customers came to the door and left while i was in there not realizing they were closed (yeah i was that guy, my bad). That was approximately 10 minutes. So if they're turning away three customers every ten minutes, that's about 18 an hour (witness the math skills). I don't know what the actual average purchase per customer is, but i'd say it's in the neighborhood of 3-10 dollars. Let's call it 5. That's $90/hr they're turning away. I'm just sayin'.
author: player z.

description: Average bagels / below average pizza (I always kick myself for getting my 2am slice here instead of Cable Car around the corner)... BUT my utmost appreciation for staying open late! It boggles my mind how early things close in this city. They totally saved me with a post-Obama-rama slice a couple nights ago, Thanks Katz!
author: Stephanie P.

description: Cruising the mission its always fun. I m all over town, but I m doing it in the morning, be sure to stop by at the katz Bagel. This "bagel-ry" its been in town for a while and the make they own bagels. Lots of things are good there. I really like because all the workers are latinos like me who came to this country to work and found better lifes. But what really make me comeback every time it is the low carb bagels, combined with smoked salmon. They are not like any other business, they really load your bagel with lox. I feel good because for $ 6 dollars for the lox low carb and $1.50 coffe I dont have to eat again for hours. Giving this food and service  you guys will keep seem me there as much as I can.  I heard that now they got some really tasty pizza, something that I haven't tried yet, but base on my friends reccomendations, that s the next BOOM.
author: montoya m.

description: Their chai was slightly warm, not hot. It fizzled out quick. Their bagel with cream cheese and jam was average..not too hard to mess up that order. Do wish they would toast it a little more, but I think that's my bad. I need to actually ask for it toasted, give me a little crunch!
author: Stephanie J.

description:
As far as bagel sandwiches go --5 stars.  I agree with the hung-over comments as well...after eating here I was definitely on the way to recovery.
The scrambled eggs they make are fluffy and yummy and the veggies are fresh.  
Cheap too!
author: Amy C.

description: Good breakfast sandwiches. Cool exterior sign. Amazingly quick assembly line & friendly people. Too many hipsters.
author: Tom C.

description: Love this place!  Great bagels, terrific coffee, wonderful staff!!
author: Bonnie W.

description: I love reviewing bagels or pizza places because it can piss off ex-East Coasters/New Yorkers so much and I love pissing off ex-East Coasters/New Yorkers.  I love Katz bagels!  Being Vegan, I really love Katz bagels because of the Chive Tofutti.  But, really, their bagels are sooooo good!  So, let the insecure East Coast/New Yorker snobbery begin.  It makes my wonder why they move out here in the first place.  :)
author: Roy J.

description: I think this is the best pizza place within a block of 16th and Valencia.  Sure there is a certain je ne sais quoi to the thin slices from Arinell.  And certainly Cable Car (or whatever it is called now) serves up a nice harty slice (good for absorbing the alcohol after a night on the town).   But Katz strikes the perfect balance.  Plus, the are always empty so you get quick and friendly service all the time.  Maybe not that they have renamed themselves Pizza 16 people will realize what they are missing.
author: Lenza M.

description: Boy do I loves me some bagels!!! The bagels here are pretty yummy! I must say they are smaller than Noah's, but it seems like you get more packed on in your bagel at Katz. I haven't walked away unsatisfied yet. The prices are reasonable and the service it fairly quick, which is good when you don't have a lot of time to spare.
author: Crystal B.

description: Great pizza and service!  Really enjoyed the Katz pizza and pizza by the slice, and the prices were really reasonable!
author: Michael W.

description: These are pretty much the best bagels available.
author: Nat O.

description: Excellent service, cheap prices, and freshly made ingredients.  The pizza was decent for a thinner-style crust, but nothing amazing.
author: laura f.

description:
My morning crankiness from my new 9-5 schedule is eased early in the AM when I walk into Katz and see the smiling faces within. What a friendly staff; so peppy and organized, these guys are really on point!

Also, props for having a fully stocked Odwalla selection + NYT.
author: Matt T.

description:
People, we are in one of the food capitols of the world and no one in the Bay Area can make a decent bagel.  This place is a complete outrage - Why have so many recommended it to me when they sell crappy stale bagels that taste and feel like they've been sitting on shelf for a week -

I thought legitimate bagel places sell their day (or three or four) old bagels thrown in plastic bags for a huge discount

At Katz's you get to pay full price for them - Best bagel in the City?? give me a break - can I give a place no stars??
author: Jaime A.

description: Why was my cinnamon raisin bagel SO SMALL this morning? I'm hoping it was a fluke. Extra star for plentiful cream cheese and friendly Spanish-speaking staff. They even gave a cup of water to a homeless man who walked in. Compassionate capitalism?
author: Dave K.

description: I swear to Buddha I'm more productive at work when I come in post- Katz whole-wheat-with-veggie-cream-cheesed and latted. If only it weren't $6+, it would be a lot easier to rationalize a daily habit.
author: Alyssa R.

description: I have to give this place 2 stars for being just not as good as Noah's.  For some reason, the cream cheese is a little too thin and therefore is not as good.
author: Joanna S.

description: Completely friendly neighborhood bagel shop with a really cool wall of neighborhood faces.
author: Melissa Y.

description: I eat Katz bagels quite frequently being that I'm 7 months pregnant.  My favorite is the whole wheat bagel with the lox, cream cheese, red onion and capers....delicious!!  Try a  non-fat latte too, fantastic service is the best.
author: jesse h.

description: Every once in a while I need to grab a quick breakfast before getting on Bart, and Katz is always my stop.  Not because the bagels are awesome - they're pretty standard, really nothing special - but because it's so convenient.  The people who work there are really friendly, but that doesn't make the bagels any more delicious.  During my jalapeno kick a few weeks ago I was grievously disappointed by the lack of flavor in their jalapeno bagel.  But, when I need a quick bagel fix, it's nice to know that Katz is just down the block, happily waiting to serve me a mediocre bagel on my way to work.
author: Rachel B.

description: A perfect stop on my walk to the BART. A million times better than Noah's.
author: Adrienne G.

description: It's quite likely that I'm just used to stale bagels, but the bagels here just seem a little too soft for my tastes. However, the great 'normal-sized' lattes and atmosphere bring the whole experience up a notch, making this one of my favourite places to relax with breakfast on a weekend morning.
author: Glen M.

description: Best bagels in the city. Never crowded. I'm in and out with a fresh bagel in a brown paper bag in less than 5 minutes.
author: Jen B.

description:
Beware!

Service sucks!  Not only did I wait 10 minutes for a bagel while there were several workers in the shop, I did not get the bagel how I wanted it (it came toasted, which I don't like and didn't ask for; and there are no signs saying that they are automatically toasted unless otherwise requested).  When I walked the 1 mile round-trip back, I was treated like a criminal because I wanted to return the bagel.  The staff spoke rudely in Spanish, which they mistakenly believed I did not understand -- they thought that I was scamming for a free bagel (yeah, right).   I would as soon have given the bagel to the neighborhood street people.

I gave it one star since I had heard that they had decent bagels, but I couldn't tell from the one bite I took.  And if you don't understand Spanish, they may be talking smack about you, too.

(Oh yea, I have lived in the Mission for 30 years (when I am not out living in other parts of the world so I am not the Marina yuppie customer Nomad G warns about.)
author: sweaterhead x.

description: Nice quality bagel, egg, cheese and sausage for $4.25 plus tax. Thumbs up.
author: Nick C.

description: Service is fast and consistent. It is the ideal place to grab a bagel before work. It is also a wonderful choice for lunch. Katz has always served sandwiches and salads and now two of three Katz locations offers freshly made pizzas.
author: Jenny H.

description: The closest I can come to bagels in SF (where most are rolls with holes passed as bagels) that taste good. I regularly order an  Everything with avocado, hummus and sprouts and it is the bomb. I always order lattes here as well. I don't know why, but they've got the best foam in the area. Missing a star only because the ambience leaves a bit to be desired. The customer service here is great, and even with a line you're never waiting for long. Haven't tried the pizza.
author: Lisa P.

description: Best bagels I've found in SF. No, they're not as good as your great NYC bagels, but what do you expect on the West Coast? Crispy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside, and their chive cream cheese is my favorite. Very nice staff, and they make a mean latte too. But what the hell is up with the pizza? Why ruin a good bagel with pizza? Loose the pizza and focus on the BAGELS.
author: G G.

description: a bit of a pain that it's cash only, but the lox spread (complete with fresh green onions) makes up for the minor inconvenience.
author: kristen m.

description: Had a toasty onion bagel with veggie spread here and it was great! Not gritty like a Noah's spread I have had the displeasure of experiencing. I'll definitely hit this place when I am craving finely chopped veggies mixed with cream cheese!
author: Erin C.

description: bad bagels and bland sandwiches.  i know i shouldn't expect east coast quality bagels out here, but come on, noah's is better than this crap.
author: Steve S.

description: pretty damn good pizza. they made individual slices to order. i think i've had their bagels....they're ok.
author: Anita C.

description:
so a friend wanted to go here because the place is raved to have better bagels than the ones in New York so he wanted to check it out.  you definitely can't miss this place because it has a big-o bagel in front of the store.
it felt like a hole in the wall and we were excited because it was 7:45 am and we figured we would get fresh bagels.  yes, we got our bagels fresh but was it all that?  NOPE!  it was not your "regular" size bagel but smaller (maybe i'm too use to the supersize foods in US).  and granted i do love cream cheese but boy did they give me WAY too much cream cheese.  i guess more cream cheese is suppose to make up for the size?!
the employees were nice but i was turned off by the random homeless person that wandered into the store to solicit...the employees did nothing to prevent their customers from being harassed INSIDE the store.
to say the least, we were disappointed but my friend is determined to try this place again...good luck to him.
author: Hanh L.

description: I fell in love with the Lox Bagel here.  Imagine a toasty sesame bagel with just enough cream cheese, succulent and generous slices of lox, topped with capers, tomatoes, onions, and sprouts....heaven.  I rarely eat here because Parking sucks in this area.  On the rare occasions that I have eaten here, I enjoy looking at the photos they have displayed of neighborhood folks ranging from babies to senior citizens.  I know these pictures are true locals as my friend's picture is displayed here.
author: Maryanne D.

description: the marguerita pizza was shockingly good. this comes from a pizza snob new yorker. ok, the crust could have been a bit more crispy, but this pizza still surprised me. the sauce was extremely good, the cheese was plentiful, the large basil leaves and freshly sliced tomatoes were carefully  placed making the pizza gourmet looking- and yes, very good.
author: barbara r.

description: I eat at this place all the time. It's so good I'll go there on Saturday afternoons after sleeping in and have bagels for lunch. The best bagels in SF by far. The service is amazing. This place is always packed and the people working here are still able to handle everyone quickly. I almost feel bad for the workers here because the crowd at this place is often filled with a bunch of yuppie white people (even though it's in the Mission). I've seen so many rude customers complaining about every little possible thing. Sometimes I just want to slap them because it's a disgrace. The people who work at this place are working like dogs probably for low wages and they still always are polite, quick, and professional. I've seen some of these people working at 2am at night baking the bagels for the next day.  I'm sick of all the Marina wanna-be yuppies in the Mission. This place still rocks. Just ignore the customers.
author: Hmmm W.
